header.title: Getting Started

chapter.p: This section describes examples of how to use the Public Key API. Keys and certificates used in the following sections are generated only for testing the Public Key application.
Some shell printouts in the following examples are abbreviated for increased readability.

section.title: PEM Files
section.p: Public-key data (keys, certificates, and so on) can be stored in Privacy Enhanced Mail (PEM) format. The PEM files have the following structure:
A file can contain several BEGIN/END blocks. Text lines between blocks are ignored. Attributes, if present, are ignored except for Proc-Type and DEK-Info, which are used when DER data is encrypted.

section.title: Encoding Public-Key Data to PEM Format
section.p: If you have public-key data and want to create a PEM file this can be done by calling functions public_key:pem_entry_encode/2 and pem_encode/1 and saving the result to a file. For example, assume that you have PubKey = 'RSAPublicKey'{}. Then you can create a PEM-"RSA PUBLIC KEY" file (ASN.1 type 'RSAPublicKey') or a PEM-"PUBLIC KEY" file ('SubjectPublicKeyInfo' ASN.1 type).
The second element of the PEM-entry is the ASN.1 DER encoded key data:

section.title: RSA Public-Key Cryptography
section.p: Suppose you have the following private key and a corresponding public key:

list.item: PrivateKey = #'RSAPrivateKey{}' and the plaintext Msg = binary()

section.p: Then you can proceed as follows:
Encrypt with the private key:
section.code: RsaEncrypted = public_key:encrypt_private(Msg, PrivateKey), Msg = public_key:decrypt_public(RsaEncrypted, PublicKey),
section.p: Encrypt with the public key:
section.code: RsaEncrypted = public_key:encrypt_public(Msg, PublicKey), Msg = public_key:decrypt_private(RsaEncrypted, PrivateKey),

note.p: You normally do only one of the encrypt or decrypt operations, and the peer does the other. This normaly used in legacy applications as a primitive digital signature.

section.title: Digital Signatures
section.p: Suppose you have the following private key and a corresponding public key:

list.item: PrivateKey = #'RSAPrivateKey{}' or #'DSAPrivateKey'{} and the plaintext Msg = binary()

section.p: Then you can proceed as follows:
section.code: Signature = public_key:sign(Msg, sha, PrivateKey), true = public_key:verify(Msg, sha, Signature, PublicKey),

note.p: You normally do only one of the sign or verify operations, and the peer does the other.

section.p: It can be appropriate to calculate the message digest before calling sign or verify, and then use none as second argument:
section.code: Digest = crypto:sha(Msg), Signature = public_key:sign(Digest, none, PrivateKey), true = public_key:verify(Digest, none, Signature, PublicKey),

section.title: SSH Files
section.p: SSH typically uses PEM files for private keys but has its own file format for storing public keys. The public_key application can be used to parse the content of SSH public-key files.

section.title: RFC 4716 SSH Public-Key Files
section.p: RFC 4716 SSH files looks confusingly like PEM files, but there are some differences:
section.code: 1> {ok, SshBin} = file:read_file("ssh2_rsa_pub"). {ok, <<"---- BEGIN SSH2 PUBLIC KEY ----\nAAAA"...>>}
section.p: This is equivalent to calling public_key:ssh_decode(SshBin, rfc4716_public_key):

section.title: Creating an SSH File from Public-Key Data
section.p: If you got a public key PubKey and a related list of attributes Attributes as returned by ssh_decode/2, you can create a new SSH file, for example:
section.code: N> SshBin = public_key:ssh_encode([{PubKey, Attributes}], openssh_public_key), <<"ssh-rsa "...>> N+1> file:write_file("id_rsa.pub", SshBin). ok
